article:
'Tuberculosis treatment' refers to the medical treatment of the infectious
disease tuberculosis (TB).

The standard "short" course treatment for TB is isoniazid (along with pyridoxal
phosphate to obviate peripheral neuropathy caused by isoniazid), rifampicin
(also known as rifampin in the United States), pyrazinamide, and ethambutol for
two months, then isoniazid and rifampicin alone for a further four months. The
patient is considered cured at six months (although there is still a relapse
rate of 2 to 3%). For latent tuberculosis, the standard treatment is six to nine
months of isoniazid alone.

If the organism is known to be fully sensitive, then treatment is with
isoniazid, rifampicin, and pyrazinamide for two months, followed by isoniazid
and rifampicin for four months. Ethambutol need not be used.
